text: right well you know the the the history
of research on framing really spans
across several different disciplines uh
social psychology sociology political
science and and Linguistics um the the
basic research methodology I actually
argue that deductively you can start
based on past research early research it
was first done in the nuclear energy
debate and then apply to biotechnology
and I argue applies to climate change
the teaching of evolution a roughly
generalizable set of frames or latent
meanings that appear to happen over and
over again uh across science debates um
you can start with that set of sort of
reoccurring meetings and on any
particular issue then do focus groups
polling in-depth interviews as a way to
figure out for what particular public do
these lat means really resonate or apply
and then when trying to connect the
scientific topic to something they
already know what are the frame devices
what are the catchphrases what are the
comparisons to history what are the
metaphors what are the stories who are
the best spokes people uh what are the
examples to use that really hit home and
activate this interpretive
meaning well in in fact actually there's
nothing wrong with simplification I mean
often times you have to simplify for an
audience that doesn't already have the
necessary background to understand a
very complex sometimes uncertain
scientific topic um and it and and in
fact as as as I talked about earlier if
if you can shift the mental box for the
audience if you can take an issue that's
unfamiliar to them and suddenly
connected to something that they already
understand or is familiar to them or
they already care about that activates
interests it activates understanding and
activates motivation then to pay really
good attention to the good science
content that's out there say the really
good news coverage on the science issue
um so for example on on stem cell
research when stem cell research first
came along in 2001 um few people have
ever heard about the issue um and in
fact people that were uh fighting
against uh Government funding for stem
cell research immediately put it in the
mental box of this is a moral and
religious debate similar to the issue of
abortion and that was a very effective
frame it really triggered a lot of
opposition and when Bush um when Bush
announced his compromised position in
August 2001 on the funding for stem cell
research there was majority support for
his compromised position on the other
hand when patient advocacy groups and
scientific institutions came together
after that compromise decision and
started to reframe the debate over stem
cell research as really a matter of
social progress stem cell research leads
to cures and also it's a matter of
growing the economy about economic
development now they switched it into a
familiar context that the public really
cared about when the public thinks about
science generally historically they
think about making our lives better
social progress leading to C or
technology or growing the economy um and
over the subsequent four or five years
you you saw very strong growth in public
support especially among the moderate
religious Catholics and Mainline
Protestants of of up to 20 percentage
points as that message started to get
across to the public
